conclusion: Understanding the problem involves an ideal gas changing states from A to B to C, and finding work done from B to C.
The gas is ideal, has a certain mass, and the process is shown on a p-V diagram with state A at 27°C.
Pressure and volume scales are in multiples of 10^5 Pa and 10^-3 m³.
From A to B: Pressure decreases from 3 x 10^5 Pa to 2 x 10^5 Pa, volume constant at 2 x 10^-3 m³.
From B to C: Volume increases from 2 x 10^-3 m³ to 3 x 10^-3 m³, pressure constant at 2 x 10^5 Pa.
Work done by gas during isobaric process is W = p * ΔV.
Calculate ΔV: 3 x 10^-3 m³ - 2 x 10^-3 m³ = 1 x 10^-3 m³.
Plug into work formula: W = 2 x 10^5 Pa * 1 x 10^-3 m³ = 200 J.
Work done by gas from B to C is 200 joules.
Double-check: Gas is expanding, so work is done by gas on surroundings.
Confirm units: Pressure in Pa and volume in m³ gives work in joules.
Consider other work types: Only pΔV work involved in isobaric process.
Ideal gas means no changes in potential or kinetic energy.
Temperature at state A is 27°C (300 K), not relevant for work calculation.
Reconsider entire process: Question asks specifically for work from B to C.
Isobaric expansion means work done by gas is positive.
First law of thermodynamics: ΔU = Q - W, but only work is needed.
